Posted: May 31, 2015
												As others pointed out, this is a vast improvement over the original Shadowrun Returns. That one played much like an endless tutorial, but Dragonfall at least offers the illusion of nonlinearity, the illusion of a vast open world  -- even though the story is pretty linear, and the world is in fact pretty cramped. But, the illusion works.It's not a faultless game by any means: I found the combat rather simplistic (and the AI often broke my suspension of disbelief), the matrix sequences are uninteresting, and I missed a more complex cyberware system as well. The choices were often lacking in depth, and rarely seemed to affect anything. But then again, the illusion often works, and the decent writing and the moral complexities it sometimes offered helped through the cracks.

Posted: June 10, 2016
												Really fun tactical SRPG with old school 2d backgrounds (awesome, gritty artwork and steampunk subject matter).  I bought Shadowrun Hong Kong first and couldn't get into it, so I was very skeptical about this one, but after reading the reviews decided to give it a shot.  Interestingly, both games have almost identical game engines and are set up very similarly, but the way this game flows makes for a completely different experience.  I've on[y played through the first few missions, but the story so far is really engrossing and very easy to follow, where Hong Kong was very disjointed and difficult to understand (at least for me).  Anyway, just so you know, you cannot rotate the screen as you can in most SRPG's.  At first I thought this was a negative, but after getting used to it, I think it works out just fine particularly given the art style.Anyway, great game with a great story so far.  Big thumbs up.H

												This was such a great game! The story was amazing, well written and engaging.  I started over after realizing the stores add stock at certain points in the game. Check them often! The end scene (or what I thought was the end scene) gives you many choices to manipulate the ending to reflect your own moral compass. Afterward, there's an epilogue that ties everything together nicely.The only negative comment I have is that all of these Shadowrun games are standalone games. You don't get to import your character and continue where you left off.Hairbrained Schemes did a fantastic job. I'm going backward and beating the first, and then I'll pick up Hong Kong. I hope the continue to make expansions!By the way, if you want to use your team mates to full advantage, play a mage or adept. All other classes are represented, and represented well!

Posted: June 15, 2015
												The best story I have ever experienced in a game. The effects your choices have on the world are massive, and you often have several ways to resolve situations, none of which are obviously good or bad. There's no voice acting, all of the story is told through reading text, and I jumped in terror at one point in the game. That's how good the writing is. I literally had nightmares about the story, and the effects my choices had. The characters in Dragonfall are some of the most memorable I have ever encountered in any medium - Glory is my favorite character in any videogame I have ever played. I haven't even mentioned the actual gameplay yet, which is also nearly perfect. Seriously, buy this game, it is amazing.

												8/10PROS:Fun tactical turn-based combat, similar to new X-COM (action points and cover system).  Lots of customization paths (Melee, Magic, Guns, Hacking, Summoning).Cyberpunk story is interesting, yet not too complicated.Multiple endings.CONS:Later on, there aren't any new skills if you decide to specialize.Limited customization for appearances.Limited selection of companions.

Posted: November 7, 2015
												So, I've read a lot of reviews for this game, and they're generally very positive, which I feel doesn't tell the whole story.SR: Dragonfall does have a great story, and is initially very fun. Reminiscent of games like Baldur's Gate or Fallout, but once you get deeper in, it has some really terrible design deicions, that make it a frustrating experience to play.Whenever you start a mission, you have to pick out your team, before you know what you're going up against. Some missions it's great to have a sniper, other missions you'd rather have your shaman with you. The problem is that you don't get any intel on these sort of things before starting, and once you've started the mission, you can't reselect your team members. Not even if you fail the mission and die, which leaves you stuck with a losing team combination, trying the same mission over and over. Tied in with this issue, the games auto-save system always overwrites the latest autosave, so if you want to be able to go back more than one save, you have to save manually all the time. If you don't and you make a mistake (such as selecting the wrong team mates, or bringing the wrong gear), then you're back to being stuck. The first time I played through, I got to the final battle, brougth the wrong crew with the wrong gear, and couldn't finish the mission. Didn't have anything other than the auto-saves, and literally had to start a new game from scratch. There was just no way to beat that mission with the team I had brought, and no way to select a new team and new gear after you died.There are also problems with the balancing of the different classes. If you pick a melee class, such as physical adept, you won't get very far in this game. You do less damage, you have to spend action points just to buff yourself up to do halfway decent damage, and once you get into close combat, the enemy just moves away and shoots you from a distance again. Close combat specialists spend 90% of the action points running around trying to get to their targets. On the other hand, going ranged combat and stacking points in rifle is just so much stronger than any of the other options, that there's really no reason to attempt anything else. A street-samurai with ranged combat spec does the same damage as a damage specced mage, but can take a hell of a lot more punishment.So yeah, SR: Dragonfall has a nice story and a cool atmosphere, but these design choices can seriously cut down on the fun you'll have.

Posted: November 7, 2015
												A neo-anarchist cyberpunk dream game. Highly recommended for fans of Planescape: Torment and Fallout 1 & 2. Without giving spoilers, I laughed out loud at the cleverness of one particular sidequest-- a run for bioware enhancement samples for a disgraced doctor. (A bit like the tone of the dystopian movie Brazil.)Although Shadowrun character creation is daunting (I played with character builds alone for 5+ hours), I'd buy all the game devs a soykaf for the solid central storyline and side missions.

Posted: November 7, 2015
												I just finished the Director's cut, having played the first version.The game was replayable and the five new missions were interesting (one is especially funny, and one is especially sad).Pros :- Berlin is a wonderful setting (the anarchist state is such a good idea !)- The cyberpunk aesthetic is very well rendered- A well balanced and challenging enough turn-based tactic game (if played in "Very hard" mode)- A good mix between RPG and tactical games- Excellent side stories (the NPC become very interesting, like real people, not just assets)- The player faces real choices, and sometimes hard dilemmas.- ReplayableContras :- Minor bugs- Some PC templates and carreers are weak as their main attributes are not useful during the RPG phase (ie. Physical Adept) ; at the opposite stand the Decker and the Shaman.- The inventory (objects cannot be given during the mission, only before)- A little bit short (25-30 hours)Conclusion : A very well written and immersive story, a love letter to the cyberpunk genre and a very good turn-based game.Let's call it a gem.By the way, it is even better than Shadowrun : Hong-Kong, and much better than Shadowrun Returns, which story lacks of a good twist.

Posted: December 20, 2016
												This is really an amazing game. I've owned it for over a year, and started it up and made a new character with different builds more then a few times, and only saw the first few missions in the game trying them out before stopping again.Just recently came back to it and decided to finish it, and that is something I recommend everyone interested in the Shadowrun Universe to do, play it through all the way to completion, the end and everything leading up to it really ramps up and plays out amazingly.There are almost infinite options for how to play the game and where you end up based on the full range of Shadowrun stats and character build options, cyberware, spells, consumables, team story lines, team upgrade options, team mate choices.The biggest thing that stood out to me with Dragonfall is just how many really huge choices you have to make in the story arc, that have really different impacts on the way it plays out. There are a few really big choices in the game that had me legitimately needing to decide what my characters feelings and point of view on that would be and what they would want out of it, because they aren't good and evil, they aren't right and wrong, they are all gray and may be good for some people or bad for others. I love RPGs but I am normally all about stats and loot and building a great fighter, not caring as much about the characters perspective, but this game really engages you in actually thinking about your character from that angle in your choices.I really enjoyed all the different ways you have access to overcome different fights or challenges, through charisma, or etiquette, spellcasting or strength, viewing things in the astral plane, or using the matrix and hacking to bypass things.It is a lot of reading, but well worth it IMO, it does a great job of making you WANT to know the answers to the questions you have, you really feel invested in it by the end and there are some crazy turns you don't see coming but make you even more interested and needing to know more, and I think some of the conversations near the end of the game are insanely deep, with many branching options that are very fulfilling and don't leave you feeling pigeon-holed or wanting, and let you talk your way out of things, and don't leave you feeling like it didn't matter either way which most games with choices do.Would 100% recommend to anyone interested in great stories, deep stat/character build RPGs, tactical/turn based combat, Elves, Dwarves, Orks, Trolls, Dragons, Magic, Martial Arts, Sniping, Grenade Launchers, Shotguns, Futuristic, Hacking, Cyberdecks, and all the other cyberpunk goodness of the 6th world.

Posted: January 8
												Shadowrun: Dragonfall is a narrative-driven cyperpunk/fantasy RPG with turn-based combat, and it's one of the better gaming experiences I've had in recent years.-----PRO:-The story is second to none with some of the best prose I've ever read in a game.-A small but unique and memorable cast of major characters.-Turn-based fights break no new ground, but the combat is diverse and manages to be mostly interesting.-Graphics are simple, but the stylish art conveys a gritty mood that's true to the franchise. A clever character creation system matches a 2D portrait to the chosen 3D preset.-GREAT soundtrack.CON:-Low-poly character models, and a lot of animations are very stiff. A fair number of blatantly recycled assets appear over and over throughout the game (and this applies to ambient audio as well).-Certain fights are just too long, sometimes devolving into frustration, and get in the way of moving the story forward.-The game is at times a bit too "retro" for its own good (e.g. describing a ventilation diagram in great detail instead of just showing it). Also, the video game-ified Shadowrun ruleset can make progression feel like a highly restricted crawl, and too few dialogues compensate for this by allowing team members to pick up the slack for the player character's weaknesses.-Non-crew shadowrunners for hire need to bring a bit more to the table, or there needs to be more chances to earn disposable income. As it is, money is precious, and the hirelings just aren't worth it.-Late in the game, a few moderately important NPCs are missing portraits. I don't know if the art budget ran out or what, but these omissions were very noticeable.-----All in all, despite a handful of minor issues, Dragonfall is a must-play for anybody interested in old-school-inspired role-playing with an A-grade story.

Posted: January 11
												I absolutely love this game. Everything from Shadowrun Returns was made even better, and I really appreciated having a real crew and stories to become invested in, regarding my team - instead of (mostly) hiring strangers to go on runs with me.All of the over the top cyberpunk flavored film noir meets fantasy meets futuristic dystopia you'd expect, is present. Even so, there are some parts of this game that really really got me this time around (especially Glory's backstory, damn!). And there are so many plot twists and levels of conspiracies throughout.If there is one complaint you see a lot about these games, its that they are too linear and should be far more open world. I don't agree with this. I understand the idea and sentiment behind those types of comments, but that set up works far better in a tabletop game with a DM, than it would in a video game. If anything, I approve of the much deeper connections and invested interests you make from having a more detailed storyline, and you can't really have that both ways.All in all its an improvement over Shadowrun Returns, which means I have nothing more to say about this game, other than clicking "recommended". Go ahead, jack into the matrix.

Posted: January 13
												I must say, I've had a great time with Shadowrun: Dragonfall. The intro mission pulled me in and the story of the game made me see the game through without playing much of anything in the meantime. The atmosphere makes any fan of cyberpunk feel right at home. The main storyline is interesting, with good buildup. The ending act left me a little bit unsatisfied as it comes out with a few predictable twists, but it's a great ride nonetheless, with good characters, good character development (talking about your teammates) and varied main and side missions.The levels itself are not vast, but they have enough areas to go through that it does not feel like a small game. Exploring every part of the levels is rewarded, atleast in some small way.The "normal" combat in the game is not bad by any means, I personally enjoyed it. It's XCOM-style, turn-based gameplay, mixing gunplay, magic, explosives, gadgets and drones. It's quite a bit of fun when it goes your way and RNG doesn't mess up your plans.The weak link of the game is the matrix-hacking sequences. The problem with them is that they are boooring, tedious to get through, fighting through repeating wave of enemies over and over again and you have to make every step in turn-based mode, making it that much slower.tl;dr- interesting main story- lots of morally grey choices- fun combat (when it goes your way)- tedious matrix (hacking) sequences- varied builds

Posted: December 9, 2016
												Shadowrun: Dragonfall is an isometric-view cyberpunk RPG with tactical turn-based combat set in 2054, and the first expansion to Shadowrun Returns. After the Awakening in 2012, which brought back magic and fantastic creatures into the world, it was plunged into chaos. Now, over forty years later, dragons and corporations rule the lands. You're one of the Shadowrunners, mercenaries for hire who are ready to do all the dirty work undercover, provided the clients are willing to pay enough money. After leaving your old team and city you worked in, you join Monika Schäfer in Berlin on a simple "milk run". Unfortunately, not all is well as you're about to stumble across a conspiracy as old as the Awakening itself...Well, let's start with the most obvious, how the game looks like. While the models aren't incredibly detailed or anything, and the backgrounds are entirely in isometric 2D, they are very rich in details and heavy atmosphere. Exploring the dark streets, sewers and labs of anarchistic Berlin is not something you'll find everywhere. You don't know what awaits you in the shadows, and the thrill of exploration, knowing that behind the next door could wait a squad of enemies, is something quite nerve-wracking at times.Sound design. While the sound effects I'd say are some of the most basic and generic ones, they're more than sufficient. This game has a very well-made soundtrack however. Most of it is electronic, something that fits the cyberpunk theme, but occassionally you get things that stand out and are really nice to listen to, like Horn and Ivory, Catharsis or Calling All Runners.Gameplay, outside of combat you're leading your team of Shadowrunners through various locations, talking to NPCs and using your skills, wits and deduction to proceed further in. In-combat, the game is a turn-based cover-based tactical strategy, where gunplay, magic and melee combat all thrive together. To note from me, even the normal difficulty setting can be plenty challenging for a player and is more than a worthy choice for your first playthrough.You can obviously create your own character and choose how to upgrade your abilities: there is a lot of options to choose from. From the five races, human, elf, dwarf, ork and troll, each having their own innate stat bonuses. Amongst the abilities, we have melee weaponry, gunplay with different types of weapons like rifles and shotguns, cyberdecking (hacking), rigging (using drones), spirit summoning, a few different schools of magic (shamanism, sorcery and chi channeling)... You can either use a premade class of sorts for your character or take it in your own hands with how you want to customize. Buying gear, including permament body enhancements called cyberware (which can be replaced but never removed once installed) which strengthen your abilities far beyond what weapons and armor can ever give you, but at the cost of losing Essence - which is your main catalyst for magical spells.The story is detailed and engaging. I often found myself just wanting to go through at least one more mission before hopping off to see what happens. Your team members all have their own stories to tell with their own side missions to complete, and there are major conspiracies to uncover. My only major complaint is that about half of the game revolves around gathering enough money to pay for the information you need towards your main goal so the story just kind of stops save for restoring extra DVDs with data and some mentions here and there for side stuffs and jobs.Another thing I really like is the amount of choices you can make during the course of story. All of them have an impact on your environment, with rumours spread around and different aftermaths. The choices you make when conversing with your teammates have an impact on how they change. Most importantly, there is almost never a clear good vs evil option - just different shades of gray, leaving it up to you to choose the one you think is morally right, knowing well that the potential consequences can be world-changing.Shadowrun: Dragonfall is an old-school RPG, and a hidden gem amongst its kind. It's dark, atmospheric, and hard at times, specifically tailored to satisfy those who like old, difficult games with a lot of depth to them. It's the kind of thing where you just want to uncover all of its secrets and find all the hidden details about the plot. I heavily reccommend this to anyone who enjoys RPGs and / or turn-based strategy games - both kinds of players will feel right at home.

Posted: March 4
												At first I have to admit, I am a Shadowrun fanboy and I really, really love this Storyline (which starts really slow but sucks you in after a cuple of hours) and also the genere.I don't think, like others say its too easy. To me the gameplay feels just fine, if I'd like it to be more of a challenge I'd go up one Difficulty, there are 5 available, I play it on "normal".What bothers me though is, after several hours (about 20 to 25) into the game it seems like more and more underperforming / bad programmed and I am pretty sure my machine has slightly more power this game needs (I5-4690K, 16GB ram, Gtx 1070, not overcklocked at all). I got several black screens while loading a save, it judders occasionally and sometimes gets stuck for a few seconds (3 -10) while i can scroll but neither move nor use abilitys. Thats kinda frustrating.There are as well a few things wrong with the gameplay itself:1. Walls do not usually count as coverage. I think thats very strange.2. The AI is really weak sometimes (running between 2 points instead of seeking coverage, shooting, etc. ...) - Occueres not too often but sometimes.3. Visibility arround corners or sometimes even in a straight line is programmed really, really bad. What happend to me once for example: Despite one character standing in a straight line to another witout any obstacles between them, they couldn't see and therefore buff / heal each other.I bought this game on sale and enjoyed playing it very much to this point. Nevertheless, if you are easy frustrated by the issues I mentioned above, you might get it on sale to give it a try or wont get it at all. I would recommend it to fans of the Shadowrun universe because of the flair and the story. I love it and would buy it again, but it's not perfect at all, keep that in mind before you buy it.

												I absolutely love this game. Everything from Shadowrun Returns was made even better, and I really appreciated having a real crew and stories to become invested in, regarding my team - instead of (mostly) hiring strangers to go on runs with me.All of the over the top cyberpunk flavored film noir meets fantasy meets futuristic dystopia you'd expect, is present. And there are so many plot twists and levels of conspiracies throughout.If there is one complaint you see a lot about these games, its that they are too linear and should be far more open world. I don't agree with this. I understand the idea and sentiment behind those types of comments, but that set up works far better in a tabletop game with a DM, than it would in a video game. If anything, I approve of the much deeper connections and invested interests you make from having a more detailed storyline, and you can't really have that both ways.All in all its an improvement over Shadowrun Returns, which means I have nothing more to say about this game, other than clicking "recommended". Posted: January 13
												I must say, I've had a great time with Shadowrun: Dragonfall. The intro mission pulled me in and the story of the game made me see the game through without playing much of anything in the meantime. The atmosphere makes any fan of cyberpunk feel right at home. The main storyline is interesting, with good buildup. The ending act left me a little bit unsatisfied as it comes out with a few predictable twists, but it's a great ride nonetheless, with good characters, good character development (talking about your teammates) and varied main and side missions.The levels itself are not vast, but they have enough areas to go through that it does not feel like a small game. Exploring every part of the levels is rewarded, atleast in some small way.The "normal" combat in the game is not bad by any means, I personally enjoyed it. It's XCOM-style, turn-based gameplay, mixing gunplay, magic, explosives, gadgets and drones. It's quite a bit of fun when it goes your way and RNG doesn't mess up your plans.The weak link of the game is the matrix-hacking sequences. The problem with them is that they are boooring, tedious to get through, fighting through repeating wave of enemies over and over again and you have to make every step in turn-based mode, making it that much slower.tl;dr- interesting main story- lots of morally grey choices- fun combat (when it goes your way)- tedious matrix (hacking) sequences- varied builds

Posted: January 23
												Dragonfall is without a doubt much better than Shadowrun Returns (Dead Man's Switch aka DMS). The game feels longer, with a more intriguing story and overall more meaningful choices. If you enjoy isometric, story-rich, turn-based, post-apocalyptic, team-building combat this is a good one. Story - *Some spoilers ahead*The comparisons to DMS is inevitable. Dragonfall's story to me was much better than DMS - there was more at stake and certainly much deeper connection to each of the team's characters. In DMS, you start the story based on a friend's dead man's switch triggering you to find his killer and collect the money held in escrow. Along they way you collect team members through the storyline. Dragonfall throws you into an existing team, with your old friend as the leader. Immediately the team members each have unique personalities. The motivations are much stronger for you to resolve the story and the grand conspiracy at the end of Dragonfall is much more interesting than DMS' cultist bug spirits. You also get to see each character grow, as you support and work through their problems with them (and maybe go through a few missions to help each of resolve something from the past). Overall, fantastic writing and I actually felt like choices mattered. I actually wanted to replay stuff and try different dialogue options.GameplayThe gameplay in Dragonfall is largely similar to DMS on the surface level. It's isometric turn-based combat, with a lot of different dialogue options that can open up depending on what skills/etiquette your character has. I roleplayed as vegeance incarnate as a decking rigger that dabbled in magic. In DMS, it really seemed that it doesn't matter if you were a jack of all trades, and whilst Dragonfall didn't punish you too harshly for it, it's highly recommended that you become a master. I also felt that Dragonfall allowed for more varied non-combat approaches which were nice. GraphicsSimilar graphics to DMS - again the character portraits are a bit ugly.SoundThe music was actually quite good this time aroundOverallWould definitely recommend buying, especially as a pack together with DMS and Hong Kong.

Posted: January 18
												Great game overall.  If you like Shadowrun, or cyberpunk in general this might be right up your alley.  The game is much improved over Shadowrun Returns in terms of its mechanics, structure, and pacing.  I personally found the writing, story and character development to also be much more enjoyable and fleshed out than Returns managed.  The only thing I would suggest you consider is if you're okay with a somewhat darker tone, since this one leans more towards the black trenchcoat side of the spectrum than the pink mohawk.Pros:+The writing (The dialogue in particular is great and the story sets a fairly consitent tone)+Never takes itself *too* seriously (Yes this is a somewhat dark story but it never forgets that it is a Shadowrun game and as such has some silly stuff as well)+Mechanically the game is fun and most possible builds seem pretty viable, even on Hard difficulty+Replay value (Both mechanically rolling different characters and narratively making different choices)+Your core team of runners is almost always available and you don't have to hire on mercs or be a jack of all trades+The soundtrack sets the mood wellCons:-Too many unavoidable ambushes (Open a door, enemies get free shots on you and you cannot position your team manually, often leaving them clumped and prime targets for AoEs)-Over-reliance on a few of the etiquettes, others are fairly uselessI think that this game is a gem and probably the best computer RPG I've played since Baldur's Gate II.  At several points the game allows you to make your own connections to what is going on (What is your relationship to Monika? What sort of Shadowrunner ARE you?)  I love that it allows you to have teammates do things if your character can't deal with certain skillchecks (Have a low strength decker? Get Eiger or Glory to force a door for you!)  At its best it feels a bit like an actual tabletop RPG with all the dice-rolling abstracted out.  Even at its worst it's a pretty fun tactical RPG.  I'd absolutely recommend it to anyone who wants a good RPG or digs Shadowrun's aesthetic.

												Pros:-Great Story-Gameplay is solid, classic turn based combat off of the table top version-The talent tree actually does alot and effects how you play-The characters are really well developed and diverse in personality-The setting is amazing, visually and allNuetral:-Lots of Text (not really con if you don't mind reading) and there is no voice acting, which I feel in the end helps becuase they could put more diversity in the conversations for less money-Pretty Long storyCons:-Not really that difficult, I only had 1-2 encounters that really stopped me, and the strategy never gets too much deeper than flanking, take good cover, and optimizing the posisiton and weapons of your team-The UI for configuring your team confused me at first, but you get used to it-The team discards any items you give them at the end of an encounter-The hit boxes can be quite annoying to trigger sometimes

Posted: February 23
												Shadowrun: Dragonfall is the second part of the Shadowrun series by Harebrained Schemes and while I was not really satisfied with its predecessor Shadowrun Returns, Dragonfall gets almost everything right. Play time is longer, the gameplay is a little improved. Technically the game is still neither really beautiful nor impressive, but the screenplay is outstanding. Character design and quests are made with a lot of passion and the story is very good. In addition, the many different ways to skill your character and the many ways to solve quests (talking/hacking/fighting/drones...) will keep you well-entertained till the end, maybe also for a second playthrough.If you want to play an RPG with great story, screenplay and character design and entertaining turn-based combat in an original scenario (ufortunately there are not too many games set in the Shadowrun universe), this is for you.

Posted: February 10
												Where Shadowrun Returns built the foundation, Dragonfall raises the buildings, and the Directors Cut creates an empireBetter UI, smoother combat, and a more fleshed out storyline that has sidequests that don't detract from the main objective. The other Runners, rather than just drop-in, drop-out guns for hire, can now be fully eschewed for a cast of characters that are creatively written and endearing in unique ways. Each of their histories give an engaging insight into who they are, what they did in the past and why they are at your side now, along with a mission for each of their backstory conclusions if you uncover enough in the right fashion.I personally ran as a Rigger, with Eiger accompanying me at long range with sniper rifles, Dietrich in mid range and Glory doing close combat, but the choices of your class are up to you.This game, along with it's fellow titles: Shadowrun: Returns and Shadowrun: Hong Kong come on sale regularly with fantastic discounts for PC. It's worth getting, either on Steam, or on mobile.

Posted: June 1, 2015
 Shadowrun: Dragonfall - Director's Cut Dragonfall c'est l'extension de Shadowrun Returns devenue un jeu à part entière. Du coup on est pas vraiment face à une suite. L'histoire est indépendante du premier opus et le moteur graphique est le même. Il y a toutefois quelques améliorations mais pas de quoi casser trois pates à un canard.On est en présence d'un RPG classique en vue isométrique (un cRPG à la fallout). On gère une équipe de shadowrunner (Sortes de mercenaires undergrounds) des combats au tour par tour. Tout au long du jeu, le joueur se retrouvera face à des choix moraux. Qui influenceront plus au moins la suite de l'histoire. Le tout est admirablement bien écrit et les drames contribuent à dépeindre l'ambiance de cet univers fantasy/cyber punk.Vous aurez le droit plusieurs fins sensiblement différentes mais aussi une alternative géniale et très sombre.Cependant, sachez avant de vous lancer dans l'aventure que le gameplay n'est pas parfait, l'IA est assez énervante avec ses comportements illogiques "Salut, c'est moi le méchant et si je venais me mettre à couvert à côté de toi". Mais le plus énervant est le spam de grenades, dès lors que vous avez au moins 2 personnages suffisament proches, les enemis se mettent à lancer des grenades. C'est systématique et d'autant plus énérvant que les couvertures et endroit souvent exigus où les combats on lieux favorisent la proximité des membres du groupe.Quoi qu'il en soit, Shadowrun Dragonfall est un excellent RPG à l'ancienne, et ce qui est assez rare à notre époque.

Posted: January 18
												Fended off blood wizards and megacorporate security while scouring the matrix to free vat-grown sacrificial humans from their fate, this game achieves the juxtaposition of meat-/cyber-space that often epitomises cyberpunk action. I really, really enjoyed that. When it worked.Some of the gameplay systems are a bit questionable (ambiguous extremes in dialogue, insufficient information to form the ideal team, not being able to simply outfit your entire crew - despite the wide array of weaponry, spells and decker gear on offer), but it's an enjoyable enough narrative experience for fans of cyberpunk that it stands in spite of those flaws. The game is prone to softlock in the matrix, arbitrarily being able to fix itself after a variable amount of time: at least a few occurances in my twenty hours played, it's been alt-f4 worthy. There are a number of missable flags in this game, which in the context of playing with the sideaim of achievement acquisition is a bit disappointing. You even stand to miss out on missions outright if you're not consistently talking to everyone, or if you do things in a slightly incorrect order. That bothers me: it should at least be flagged that characters have unique dialogue. Saving early and often works to get around this, but my experience of the game featured some pretty lengthy save and load times (even playing on an SSD).Cool game. Happy to have experienced it.

												I heard about Shadowrun Returns through GameInformer, but did not actually get any of the new Shadowruns until this one came on sale. After many hours, I can happily say that I would have paid double for it. I recommend it with some caveats. It can be difficult to start, so I would suggest a guide and definitely not trying to build your character from scratch. The turn based gameplay and isometric view can be offputting, so beware. The story is solid but not anything the will win an award anytime soon. The thing that keeps the most invested are the small moments, such as being a total scumbag and taking the money because you need it. Or leaving someone to die because that is the only way you'll get out of there. The best way to put it is that it is a cyberpunk Fallout with magic. The original, isometric Fallout.TL;DR If you like slower, turn based gameplay with an isometric view, then this is the game for you. Otherwise, be cautious and test it out.

Posted: April 24
												It's hard to judge Shadowrun games. If you own just Dragonfall - DC, you'll get it over with a couple of lines like "amazing! Very cool story, engaging combat!" but if you played Returns, Dragonfall and Hong Kong, it becomes a little harder.I think in this case it's about "Quality over quantity", in comparison to Hong Kong, Dragonfall really takes the cake for quality. Even so, even quantity overflows in comparison of what Dead Man's Switch in Returns has to offer. The main campaign of Dragonfall is one of the best out there, imho, even though I still need to dig in the mods (got a couple of titles that look promising) and to be completely honest, if I had played Hong Kong before Dragonfall... dunno, I think the spark wouldn't... spark. I fell in love with Dragonfall: The Flux State, Berlin, your party and the world around are SO passionate.Options for resolving the missions are WIDE. With wide I mean that I was not prepared for it: there are a ton. Having played Returns AFTER Dragonfall I can totally see the sheer amount of dialogue options they added.Combat is better than in Returns, and bugs are non-existant. Atleast, my run was glitch-free. I enjoyed it every minute and I would recommend this over anything.To notice that I did not know anything about the Shadowrun world before this game, and I've read a lot on the wiki just to get a shape of what those various events/tidbits you find about the world are supposed to really be (Hong Kong does this a bit more than Dragonfall, but still you'll find a lot of sidequests pointing you at things happening at other cities in the world, Chicago or Seattle included).The price is a bit hefty, but it's Returns all over again: a very good official campaign, and the campaign editor. Totally recommended.10/10

Posted: April 24
												My introduction to the Shadowrun series (yeah, I know playing a game that was originally DLC for another game, Shadowrun Returns) and I gotta say I'm pretty impressed. I really dig the setting first of, it's like if the characters and creatures of Dragon Age lived in the world of Blade Runner. The story is very good, it doesn't feel like it's over stating it's welcome and does a good job and keeping you on your toes as to what the big mystery is and it's a good pay off. The characters overall are very interesting though I wish there was more development with them, you look at older RPGs like Planescape Torment and the first two KOTOR games, I really felt like I got to know my party and they interacted with each other in interesting ways. Here, we get to know some of their backstories and what their personalities are but the game doesn't go much beyond that, there are no personal missions for the characters like in Mass Effect for example but they do a good enough job with them.The combat is good. It requires very good strategy and patience especially on the harder difficulties. The role playing is also very good, you can definitely play this game your own way and portray yourself the way you want, although all of the classes have their own limitations so don't expect a street samurai to be a hacking expert which is good, it makes the player have to work around their limitations for a solution instead of looking for the easy way out all the time. I don't like that you can't control your party members outside of combat. What if I'm approaching a room and I want my party members positioned in a certain way? Well, tough luck, You can't (still not as bad as the PS2 version of Persona 3 where you can't control your party members at all)The graphics are average especially with the character models, it's an indie game so I won't be too hard on it but artistically, it gets the job done. It's suppose to make you feel like you're in a dystopian city and it succeeds at that although I find the environments kinda samey. I'm not saying make it like Zelda with fire, water, forest environments or whatever but they could've definitely done more with it than gray hallways, sewers, and more gray hallways. Games like Deus Ex and System Shock I feel did a better job with freshening up the environments and levels while still being consistent with their worldThe music I also think is okay. There are some good tracks here and there but overall it's not a soundtrack I see myself desperating wanting to listening toOverall, It's very good game for fans of cyberpunk. It's not perfect, it's no Deus Ex, System Shock 2, or Snatcher but if you're looking for another cyberpunk game to hold you over until Cyberpunk 2077 finally comes out. This is a solid one to check out and I give it an 8/10
